awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Carbon-encapsulated sulfur cathodes for next generation batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to enable next-generation lithium battery technologies that are integral in transitioning toward increased renewable energy deployment. In particular, the project has the potential to overcome obstacles to widespread electric vehicle (EV) adoption including battery capacity limitations, high battery cost, and supply chain issues.  EVs currently account for a significant majority of the lithium battery market and this market share will likely increase dramatically as deployment of EVs increases in coming years. The aforementioned issues with lithium battery technologies must be addressed for EVs to reach their envisioned potential. This STTR project seeks to advance a novel process for the production of a critical battery component – the battery cathode. 

This STTR Phase I project proposes to advance lithium sulfide (Li-S) battery viability using a novel approach to cathode production. Lithium sulfide  batteries can provide more than double the gravimetric energy density of current lithium batteries, but Li-S batteries suffer from a short cycle life due to the poor retention of polysulfide species which are formed at the cathode during cycling. If these polysulfide species are able to diffuse away from the cathode, they participate in several detrimental reactions and interactions with both the electrolyte and anode, and the battery is damaged. This project seeks to retain the sulfur and polysulfides within the cathode using encapsulation within a carbon scaffold. Specific research will include assessments of the maximum sulfur loading that can be achieved in the carbon scaffold, the extent to which the carbon scaffold can be rendered electrically conductive, construction of cathodes from the sulfur-loaded carbon scaffold, and tests of the performance of batteries constructed from these cathodes. In addition, a technoeconomic analysis of the cathode technology will be performed to assess its potential in the context of current lithium battery technology. Expected outcomes include demonstrated technical and economic viability of the cathode technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The demand for better batteries is ever-present in our society, driven by our increasing reliance on portable electronics and electric vehicles. Current battery technologies, such as lithium-ion batteries, face challenges related to cost, performance, and the use of rare materials. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have emerged as a promising alternative, offering higher performance at lower cost and with less reliance on rare materials.

This project focused on developing carbon foam-based lithium-sulfur batteries, a novel approach that holds the potential to revolutionize energy storage. Carbon foams were produced from a variety of lignocellulosic biomasses using a high-pressure pyrolysis method. These biomasses, including wood, grasses, and lignin, are renewable resources, making the carbon foam production process environmentally friendly.

One of the key objectives of the project was to increase the amount of sulfur that could be encapsulated within the produced foams. To achieve this, the project team developed new methods, including the addition of surfactants and the use of novel sulfur sources. These methods were successful, with the project achieving a sulfur loading greater than 45%. This is a significant advancement, as higher sulfur loading is crucial for improving the energy density and performance of lithium-sulfur batteries.

Additionally, a model was created to predict the sulfur content of the produced carbon foams. This model was validated against experimental data, providing important insights into the reaction mechanisms during pyrolysis. The model can be used to help increase sulfur loading in future iterations of the battery development process, further improving their performance and efficiency. While the project has made significant progress, further work is needed to perfect the heat treatment process of the carbon foams. Heat treatment is essential for optimizing the structure and electrical conductivity of the foams, ultimately improving the performance of the batteries.

The outcomes of this project have far-reaching implications. By developing carbon foam-based lithium-sulfur batteries from renewable lignocellulosic biomasses, the project has laid the foundation for a more sustainable and environmentally friendly approach to energy storage. These batteries have the potential to offer higher energy density, longer cycle life, and lower cost compared to traditional lithium-ion batteries, making them ideal for a wide range of applications, from portable electronics to electric vehicles and grid storage.

 


Last Modified: 05/09/2024
Modified by: Kurt W Stahlfeld
